Title:
In Colombia, the Eurasian Amanita muscaria is expanding its
range into a native, tropical Quercus humboldtii forest
Abstract:
To meet a global demand for timber, tree plantations were
established in South America during the first half of the 20th century.
Extensive plantations of non-native species are found in Brazil, Chile,
Argentina and Uruguay. In Colombia, miscellaneous plantations were
established during the 1950s, during a period of intensive local
logging, when policies to limit deforestation in native Quercus
humboldtii forests were established. One unforeseen consequence of
planting non-native trees was the simultaneous introduction and
subsequent persistence of ectomycorrhizal fungi. We sought to document
the origins of the introduced Amanita muscaria currently found in exotic
plantations of the Mexican species Pinus patula, North American species
P. taeda, and Australian species Acacia melanoxylon and Eucalyptus
globulus. We also describe the spread of the fungus; in Colombia,
Amanita muscaria is establishing a novel association with native Q.
humboldtii and has spread to a local Q. humboldtii forest. According to
a Bayesian phylogeny and haplotype analysis based on the nuclear rDNA
Internal Transcribed Spacer ITS1-5.8S-ITS2 (ITS barcode) region, A.
muscaria individuals associated with the four exotic plant species, and
those colonizing Q. humboldtii roots, have a Eurasian origin and belong
to two Eurasian haplotypes. This is the first time the spread of an
introduced mutualist fungus is reported into native Colombian Q.
humboldtii forests. To arrest its spread, we suggest the use of local
inocula made up of native fungi, instead of inocula of introduced
fungi.
